What's the best warm up for BJJ?
The truth is, there's many ways to skin this cat.
However, this routine that I'm about to take you through
is simple, it's effective,
and for that reason, it is our best warm up for BJJ Whitebelts.
So when we're trying to put together the ideal warm up,
we want to take into account a few things.
Time is of the essence.
Generally, you don't have a lot of time
between arriving at the academy to when the class starts.
So we want to have a warm up that can slot in
to that short space of time you have.
So we're thinking five to 10 minutes at the most.
Now obviously, you're going to do your class warm up,
but if you know us, we're not big fans
of the typical Jiu-Jitsu class warm up.
So what we're doing here is designed to complement
what you're then going to be going and doing in class.
Couple of other major things we want to consider.
Mobility.
Most of us will have restrictions in how we move,
and this will come down to tightness through the joints.
We can look at the body in two simple parts.
We've got the lower body and we've got the upper body.
Now the tighter your lower body is,
that's going to hold you back from being able
to play a strong top game, being able to base,
being able to defend takedowns and being able to pass.
But it's also going to make guard really hard for you.
You notice that a lot of guard play in Jiu-Jitsu
involves articulation of the hips.
Pull your knees into the chest, rotate the hips,
a lot of internal and external rotation.
So if you're tight through the hips,
all of that stuff's going to be really tricky for you.
So we want to make sure we get a really good dose
of hip mobility in our warm up.
For the upper body, we also want to give a little bit of time
to opening up through the shoulders
and also through the spine and upper back.
Again, the tighter and more restricted you are
in these areas, the less you're going to be able
to move on the mats, and probably the quicker you're going
to get tapped out.
So if we can have better movement,
we have more options when we find ourselves
in a sticky situation.
Now there's two other key components to this warm up.
First is making sure we're getting good activation
of key muscle groups.
And for a lot of us, we spend a lot of time
sitting down all day, and the glutes become
relatively inactive.
The glutes are what drive the hips,
and it's really important that we get these things fired up.
So we've got one of our favorite drills in here
to make sure we're getting those glutes activated.
It's going to help you be more athletic on the mats,
and it's also going to protect your lower back.
And then the last piece is that we want to start
to get some athletic work done.
So we want to get something that's going to move us
into this dynamic state of Jiu-Jitsu training,
and we're using a hopping drill for that.
And the beauty of the hopping drill is twofold.
It gets you activated, it gets your proprioceptive
juices flowing, it's going to get your nervous system switched on,
but it's also going to help to protect the joints
of the lower body.
So the ankles, the knees, specifically, and the hips,
all benefit from having some hopping drills
in your warm-ups.
Really important.
We've only got five drills, we've only got a short space of time.
We want to make sure each of those drills
gives as many benefits as possible.
Let's take a look at the drills.
First drill we're looking at is called the table top press.
And we're using this drill to essentially
open up through the upper body.
So you're going to get a nice stretch through the peck,
through the shoulders, down into the biceps.
You're also going to be getting a bit of mobility
through the forearm and wrist.
And then it's just going to be doing a bit of work
to get the hips active as well.
Table top press is really simple to get into.
I'm seated, I have my feet at hip width,
and then I'm going to place my hands behind me.
Now I want to have my hands at a round shoulder width,
okay, so I don't want to have them too wide.
I want to have a nice kind of strong position here on them.
Now you can play with which direction your fingers are pointing.
The easiest starting point is to have your fingers pointing back.
From here I pull my shoulders back and down,
I brace through the midsection.
So I'm keeping some tension in my abs.
And then I drive through the heel
and squeeze my glutes at the top.
All right, it's important as I go through the press
that I'm keeping the shoulder blades pulled back and down,
okay, and you notice I'm keeping my abs slightly braced
so that I'm not just arching my back
and sticking my tummy out.
I want to keep a neutral spine position
so that I push the stretch into my shoulders and my hips.
Now to change what's happening there a little bit,
you can turn the fingers to face outwards.
Good work there.
It changes slightly the stretch that you're getting
through the shoulder, and then you can even
for a slightly more challenging variation
try the fingers pointing forwards.
Good work.
You're going to perform 10 to 15 reps
and then I want you to hold the last repetition
for 10 seconds.
The second drill we're going to perform
is called an active pigeon.
And I'm going to show you two variations of this.
One that's a bit easier, one that's a bit more challenging.
This drill is going to help to loosen up or open up
all this stuff around the glutes and the lower back
and it's going to get your hip rotation
moving nice and fluid, okay?
So the setup will be here in a lunge position, okay?
Now I'm just going to push this knee outwards
and I'm going to place my hands on the floor.
My foot is positioned in the middle of my hands here, okay?
I'm not directly alongside the foot,
I'm just in front of it.
From here I'm going to keep a long spine
and I'm going to pull this knee down towards the ground.
I take it as far as I can,
feeling a good stretch on the outside of the hip
and then I reset.
I'm going to perform my repetitions here.
On each rep I'm trying to get a little bit deeper
by taking my knee closer to the floor.
Now if you want to make it harder,
you're going to lift the back knee off the ground
and you'll perform the reps here.
There's now more load in the stretch which I like,
but if you feel it's a bit challenging for you,
stick with the knee and if you need to make it
a touch easier again, you can also just hang out
in this position, you don't have to keep moving through it.
You can just stay there for 30 to 45 seconds.
For the active pigeon, I want you to perform
one set of 10 to 15 reps and then you'll
hold the last repetition for 10 seconds.
Third drill we're looking at is the Kossak squat.
We're using this drill to open up through
the inside aspect of the hips,
which again is obviously very important
for how you play your guard,
but we're also using this to start to warm up the legs
to do a bit of work because what's happening
in a Kossak squat is we're performing a squat
and it's leaning into a single leg.
So it's starting to load that leg up,
load the knee joint, load the ankles
and this is really important because once we get on the mat,
people are going to be jumping all over you,
you're going to have load on you.
So it's the ideal thing to be able to replicate
some of that in our warm up so the body is prepared.
So for this feet are out around double shoulder width,
you'll have to play around width for you.
And essentially what I'm doing is I'm leaning out to one side
and I'm starting to squat down.
Now as I do this, you'll notice I rotate this foot
towards the ceiling, my knee is locked
and the foot is pulled back and I will bring myself
as low as is comfortable.
I will then move to the other side and perform the squat here.
Now if you're new to this or if you really tight
through the lower body, you may not be able to get particularly deep.
What's important is that you go as deep as you can.
So if you're finding a big stretch here and this is tough,
that's great.
Keep working with it and over time, your range will improve.
But if you're feeling pretty mobile
and you've got more depth to it,
I want you to take it as deep as you can
while staying tight and controlled through the position.
So I'm keeping a bit of tension in my abs.
I'm making sure that the squatting knee
is positioned over the toes.
It's not buckling in like this, okay?
And I'm staying as upright as possible through my torso.
Note on the caustic squat, if you have tight ankles,
you might find it hard to keep your foot flat
when you come into the bottom position
and your heel will lift off the ground like this.
It's a really good goal from an ankle mobility perspective
to try to keep the heel down.
But in terms of getting the hips warmed up
and getting us prepped for Jiu-Jitsu,
it's totally okay if that heel does lift off the ground.
The most important thing is that you're staying controlled

For the caustic squat, I want you to perform a set
